headline: Nvidia director Harvey Jones sells $44 million in shares held for over three decades
summary: Nvidia board member Harvey Jones sold more than $44 ​million worth of company stock, a ‌regulatory filing showed on Wednesday.  Jones, who has ‌served as a director at the chipmaker since 1993, disposed of 250,000 shares on December 15 at an average ⁠price of $177.33 ‌per share, the filing showed.  The shares were part of a ‍stake held since 1997, two years before Nvidia went public in 1999.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Another AI Selloff
summary: The Dow fell 228 points led by Caterpillar and Nvidia.  The PHLX Semiconductor Index that is home to 30 major chip stocks dropped 3.8% by the closing bell.  Nvidia, Broadcom, Tesla and Google-parent Alphabet all shed 3-4% by the closing bell, racking up a total of $431 billion in lost market cap for the day.

headline: AI-Themed Stocks Take More Hits, Sending Nasdaq Lower
summary: Tech stocks slid on Wednesday, continuing to drag down major indexes, as investors worried about the future of AI-themed stocks.  The Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1.8%, while the S&P 500 slipped 1.2%, the biggest falls for each benchmark in nearly a month.  Tech giants Google-parent  Alphabet Nvidia  and  Tesla  all fell more than 3%, leading the Magnificent Seven growth stocks lower, while the Dow industrials fell 0.5%, dragged lower by a fall in  Caterpillar  shares.

content.title: AI-Themed Stocks Take More Hits, Sending Nasdaq Lower

headline: Salesforce and Other AI Stocks That Can Catch Up to the Pack
summary: Nvidia Microsoft  and other prominent artificial-intelligence stocks are seeing bouts of selling. The worry there is that returns on their massive AI investments might disappoint the market’s expectations.

headline: Google teams with Meta’s PyTorch to chip away at Nvidia’s moat, Reuters says
summary: Investing.com -- Alphabet Inc’s (NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google is intensifying efforts to make its proprietary artificial intelligence hardware more compatible with the industry’s leading software, a move aimed at challenging NVIDIA Corp’s (NASDAQ:NVDA) grip on the AI computing market, Reuters reported Wednesday. The initiative, known internally as "TorchTPU," focuses on optimizing Google’s Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) to run PyTorch, an open-source framework originally developed by Meta Platforms Inc.

content.title: Google teams with Meta’s PyTorch to chip away at Nvidia’s moat, Reuters says
content.summary: Investing.com -- Alphabet Inc’s (NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google is intensifying efforts to make its proprietary artificial intelligence hardware more compatible with the industry’s leading software, a move aimed at challenging NVIDIA Corp’s (NASDAQ:NVDA) grip on the AI computing market, Reuters reported Wednesday. The initiative, known internally as "TorchTPU," focuses on optimizing Google’s Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) to run PyTorch, an open-source framework originally developed by Meta Platforms Inc.

headline: Exclusive-Google works to erode Nvidia's software advantage with Meta's help
summary: Alphabet's Google is working on a new initiative to make its artificial intelligence chips better at running PyTorch, the world’s most widely used AI software framework, in a move aimed at weakening Nvidia's longstanding dominance of the AI computing market, according to people familiar with the matter.  The effort is part of Google's aggressive plan to make its Tensor Processing ​Units a viable alternative to Nvidia's market-leading GPUs.  TPU sales have become a crucial growth engine of Google's cloud revenue as it seeks to prove to investors that its AI investments are generating returns.

content.title: Exclusive-Google works to erode Nvidia's software advantage with Meta's help
content.summary: Alphabet's Google is working on a new initiative to make its artificial intelligence chips better at running PyTorch, the world’s most widely used AI software framework, in a move aimed at weakening Nvidia's longstanding dominance of the AI computing market, according to people familiar with the matter.  The effort is part of Google's aggressive plan to make its Tensor Processing ​Units a viable alternative to Nvidia's market-leading GPUs.  TPU sales have become a crucial growth engine of Google's cloud revenue as it seeks to prove to investors that its AI investments are generating returns.

headline: Nebius AI Cloud 3.1 Delivers Next-Generation NVIDIA Blackwell Ultra Compute with Transparent Capacity Management for AI at Scale
summary: AMSTERDAM, December 17, 2025--Nebius today announced Nebius AI Cloud 3.1, bringing next-generation NVIDIA Blackwell Ultra compute and enhanced operational capabilities to the latest release of its full-stack AI cloud platform. Version 3.1 builds on the foundations of Nebius AI Cloud "Aether", adding transparent capacity management and expanded infrastructure to deliver the operational visibility and resource-planning capabilities that customers need as they scale AI in production.

content.title: Nebius AI Cloud 3.1 Delivers Next-Generation NVIDIA Blackwell Ultra Compute with Transparent Capacity Management for AI at Scale
content.summary: AMSTERDAM, December 17, 2025--Nebius today announced Nebius AI Cloud 3.1, bringing next-generation NVIDIA Blackwell Ultra compute and enhanced operational capabilities to the latest release of its full-stack AI cloud platform. Version 3.1 builds on the foundations of Nebius AI Cloud "Aether", adding transparent capacity management and expanded infrastructure to deliver the operational visibility and resource-planning capabilities that customers need as they scale AI in production.
